speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Before discussing today’s meeting, let me briefly address recent developments in the banking sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the past two weeks, serious difficulties at a small number of banks have emerged.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: History has shown that isolated banking problems, if left unaddressed, can undermine confidence in healthy banks and threaten the ability of the banking system as a whole to play its vital role in supporting the savings and credit needs of households and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is why, in response to these events, the Federal Reserve, working with the Treasury Department and the FDIC, took decisive actions to protect the U.S. economy and to strengthen public confidence in our banking system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These actions demonstrate that all depositors’ savings and the banking system are safe.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With the support of the Treasury, the Federal Reserve Board created the Bank Term Funding Program to ensure that banks that hold safe and liquid assets can, if needed, borrow reserves against those assets at par.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This program, along with our long-standing discount window, is effectively meeting the unusual funding needs that some banks have faced and makes clear that ample liquidity in the system is available.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our banking system is sound and resilient, with strong capital and liquidity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will continue to closely monitor conditions in the banking system and are prepared to use all of our tools as needed to keep it safe and sound.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, we are committed to learning the lessons from this episode and to work to prevent episodes—events like this from happening again.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Turning to the broader economy and monetary policy: Inflation remains too high, and the labor market continues to be very tight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I understand the hardship that high inflation is causing, and we remain strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Without price March 22, 2023 stability, the economy does not work for anyone.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, without price stability, we will Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL not achieve a sustained period of long—of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The U.S. economy slowed significantly last year, with real GDP rising at a below-trend pace of 0.9 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Consumer spending appears to have picked up this quarter, although some of that strength may reflect the effects of swings in the weather across the turn of the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In contrast, activity in the housing sector remains weak, largely reflecting higher mortgage rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Higher interest rates and slower output growth also appear to be weighing on business fixed investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Committee participants generally expect subdued growth to continue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As shown in our Summary of Economic Projections, the median projection for real GDP growth stands at just 0.4 percent this year and 1.2 percent next year, well below the median estimate of the longer-run normal growth rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And nearly all participants see the risks to GDP growth as weighted to the downside.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yet the labor market remains extremely tight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Job gains have picked up in recent months, with employment rising by an average of 351,000 jobs per month over the last three months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate remained low in February at 3.6 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor force participation rate has edged up in recent months, and wage growth has shown some signs of easing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: However, with job vacancies still very high, labor demand substantially exceeds the supply of available workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: FOMC participants expect supply and demand conditions in the labor market to come into better balance over time, easing upward pressures on wages and prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median unemployment rate projection in the SEP rises to 4.5 percent at the end of this year and 4.6 percent at the end of next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation remains well above our longer-run goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the 12 months ending in January, total PCE prices rose 5.4 percent; excluding the volatile food and energy categories.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Core PCE—excluding those, core PCE prices rose 4.7 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In February, the 12-month change in the CPI came in at 6 percent, and the change in the core CPI was 5.5 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation has moderated somewhat since the middle of last year, but the strength of these recent readings indicates that inflation pressures continue to run high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median projection in the SEP for total PCE inflation is 3.3 percent for this year, 2.5 percent next year, and 2.1 percent in 2025.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The process of getting inflation back down to 2 percent has a long way to go and is likely to be bumpy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Despite elevated inflation, longer-term inflation expectations appear to remain well anchored, as reflected in a broad range of surveys of households, businesses, and forecasters, as well as measures from financial markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s monetary policy actions are guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation imposes significant hardship, as it erodes purchasing power, especially for those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are highly attentive to the risks that high inflation poses to both sides of our mandate, and we are strongly committed to returning inflation to our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At today’s meeting, the Committee raised the target range for the federal funds rate by ¼ percentage point, bringing the target range to 4¾ to 5 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we are continuing the process of significantly reducing our securities holdings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since our previous FOMC meeting, economic indicators have generally come in stronger than expected, demonstrating greater momentum in economic activity and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We believe, March 22, 2023 however, that events in the banking system over the past two weeks are likely to result in tighter Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL credit conditions for households and businesses, which would in turn affect economic outcomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is too soon to determine the extent of these effects and therefore too soon to tell how monetary policy should respond.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As a result, we no longer state that we anticipate that ongoing rate increases will be appropriate to quell inflation; instead, we now anticipate that some additional policy firming may be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will closely monitor incoming data and carefully assess the actual and expected effects of tighter credit conditions on economic activity, the labor market, and inflation, and our policy decisions will reflect that assessment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In our SEP, each FOMC participant wrote down an appropriate path for the federal funds rate based on what that participant judges to be the most likely scenario going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If the economy evolves as projected, the median participant projects that the appropriate level of the federal funds rate will be 5.1 percent at the end of this year, 4.3 percent at the end of 2024, and 3.1 percent at the end of 2025.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These are little changed from our December projections, reflecting offsetting factors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These projections are not a Committee decision or plan; if the economy does not evolve as projected, the path for policy will adjust as appropriate to foster our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will continue to make our meeting—decisions meeting by meeting, based on the totality of the vincoming data and their implications for the outlook for economic activity and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We remain committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal and to keep longer-term inflation expectations well anchored.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Reducing inflation is likely to require a period of below-trend growth and some softening in labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Restoring price stability is essential to set the stage for achieving maximum employment and stable prices over the longer run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the Fed will do everything we can to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I look forward to your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I guess our view is that the banking system is sound and it’s resilient—it’s got strong capital [and] liquidity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We took powerful actions with [the] Treasury and the FDIC, which demonstrate that all depositors’ savings are safe and that the banking system is safe.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Deposit flows in the banking system have stabilized over the last week.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the last thing I’ll say is that we’ve undertaken—we’re undertaking a thorough internal review that will identify where we can strengthen supervision and regulation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we considered—we did consider that in the days running up to the meeting, and you see the decision that we made, which I’ll say a couple things about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: First, it was supported by a very strong consensus, and I’ll be happy to explain why.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, really, it is that the intermeeting data on inflation and the labor market came in stronger than expected and, really, before the recent events, we were clearly on track to continue with ongoing rate hikes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, as of a couple of weeks ago, it looked like we’d need to raise rates over the course of the March 22, 2023 year more than we had expected at the time of the SEP in December—at the time of the Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL December meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to restoring price stability, and all of the evidence says that the public has confidence that we will do so—that we’ll bring inflation down to 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is important that we sustain that confidence with our actions as well as our words.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we also assess, as I mentioned, that the events of the last two weeks are likely to result in some tightening credit conditions for households and businesses and thereby weigh on demand, on the labor market, and on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Such a tightening in financial conditions would work in the same direction as rate tightening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In principle, as a matter of fact, you can think of it as being the equivalent of a rate hike or perhaps more than that; of course, it’s not possible to make that assessment today with any precision whatsoever.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So our decision was to move ahead with the 25 basis point hike and to change our guidance, as I mentioned, from ongoing hikes to some, some additional hikes maybe—some policy firming may be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So going forward, as I mentioned, in assessing the need for, for further hikes, we’ll be focused as always on the incoming data and the evolving outlook and, in particular, on our assessment of the actual and expected effects of credit tightening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No, I think it’s, it’s meant to refer to our policy rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Really, I would focus on, on the words “may” and “some,” as opposed to “ongoing.” Ongoing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we, we clearly were—what we were doing there was taking onboard the—trying to reflect the uncertainty about what will happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, it, it’s possible that this will turn out to have very March 22, 2023 modest effects—that these events will turn out to be very, very modest effects on the economy, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL in which case inflation will continue to be strong—in which case, you know, the path will look—might look different.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s also possible that this potential tightening will contribute significant tightening in credit conditions over time and, in principle, if that—that means that monetary policy may have less work to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We simply don’t know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, with our monetary policy, we’re, we’re really focused on macroeconomic outcomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, we’re focused on, on this potential credit tightening and what can that produce in the way of tighter credit conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think when we think about the situation with the banks, we’re focused on our—on our financial stability tools, in particular our lending facilities, the debt—sorry, the discount window, and also the new facility.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we have just come from an FOMC meeting and, you know, the people who write the minutes will be very carefully counting, but I’ll tell you what I heard.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What I heard was significant number of people saying that they anticipated there would March 22, 2023 be some, some tightening of credit conditions and that would really have the same effects as, as Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL our policies do, and that therefore they were including that in their assessment and that if that did turn out not to be the case, in principle you would need more rate hikes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So some people did reflect that in their FOMC—in their SEP forecasts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think there may also just have been—remember, this is 12 days ago.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’re trying to assess something that just is so recent and it’s people—you know, it’s very difficult, there’s so much uncertainty.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So December was a good place to start, and we wound up with—we wound up with very similar outcomes for December.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, in a way, the early—the data in the first part—the first five weeks of the intermeeting period pointed to stronger inflation and stronger labor markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that pointed to higher rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then this, this latter part kind of—the possibility of credit conditions tightening really, really offset that, effectively.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we know that we have other, other tools in effect, but no, we think our monetary policy tool works, and we think, you know, many, many banks—our rate hikes were well telegraphed to the market, and many banks have managed to handle them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The issue was really not about those specific banks, but about the risk of a contagion to, to other banks and to the financial markets more broadly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That was the issue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So Vice Chair Barr is, is of course leading that review.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And he’s responsible for it in his capacity as Vice Chair for Supervision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We—I realized, you know, right away that, that there was going to be a need for review.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so what we did was, early Monday morning, we sat down and said, “Let’s do this.” And he, he was obviously going to lead it in his capacity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t—my role was to announce it, and I get briefed on it, but I’m not involved in, in the work of it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, what actually happened, Howard, was I got the question 12 times, so it’s—maybe it’s a feature, not a bug.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Goods inflation has been coming down now for six months; it’s proceeding more slowly than we would have liked, but it’s certainly proceeding.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Housing services is, is really a matter of time passing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We continue to see the new leases being signed at much lower levels of inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s 44 percent of the—of the core PCE index, where you’ve got a story that’s ongoing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Where we didn’t have in February, and we still don’t have now, is a sign of progress in the nonhousing services sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that is, you know, that’s just something that will have to come through softening demand and perhaps some softening in labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t see that yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, that’s of course 56 percent of the index.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the story is pretty much the same.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will say that the inflation data that we got, to your point, really pointed to stronger inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s really just a question of not knowing at this point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a great deal of literature on the connection between tighter credit conditions, economic activity, hiring, and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Very large body of literature.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s, that’s the issue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don’t really see it yet, so, so people are making estimates, you know, people are publishing estimates, but it’s very kind of rule-of-thumb guesswork almost at this point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we think it’s, it’s potentially March 22, 2023 quite real and that argues for, you know, being alert as we go forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As we think about further Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL rate hikes for us, we’ll be paying attention to the actual and expected effects from that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me say what, what I think happened, and then I’ll come to the questions around supervision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, at a basic level, Silicon Valley Bank management failed badly—they grew the bank very quickly, they exposed the bank to significant liquidity risk and interest rate risk, didn’t hedge that risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We now know that supervisors saw these risks and, and intervened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know that the public saw all this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know that SVB experienced an unprecedentedly rapid and massive bank run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this is a—this is a very large group of connected depositors—concentrated group of connected depositors in a very, very fast run, faster than historical record would suggest.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So as for us—so for our part, we’re doing a review of supervision and regulation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My only interest is that we identify what went wrong here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: How did this happen is the question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Try to find that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will find that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then make an assessment of what are the right policies to put in place so that it doesn’t happen again, and then implement those policies.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It would be inappropriate for me at this stage to offer my views on what the answers might be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I simply can’t do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Vice Chair Barr is March 22, 2023 leading this, and I think he’s testifying next week.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—but that will be up to him.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL really where it is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the, the review is going to be thorough and transparent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is clear—really to your last question—it’s clear that we do need to strengthen supervision and regulation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I, I assume that there will be recommendations coming out of the report, and I, I plan on supporting them and supporting their implementation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These are not weaknesses that are—that are at all broadly through the banking system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This was—this was a bank that was an outlier in terms of both its percentage of, of uninsured deposits and in terms of its holdings of duration risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And again, supervisors did get in there, and, and they were, as you know, obviously, you know they were—they were on this issue, but nonetheless, this, this still happened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so that’s really the nature of the interview—sorry, of the review—is to discover that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we published an SEP today, as you will have seen, and it shows that basically participants expect relatively slow growth, a gradual rebalancing of supply and March 22, 2023 demand in the labor market, with inflation moving down gradually.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In that most likely case, if Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL that happens, participants don’t see rate cuts this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They just don’t.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would just say: As always, the path of the economy is uncertain, and policy is going to reflect what actually happens rather than what we write down in the SEP.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s not our baseline expectation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s going to depend.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then we’re thinking about that as effectively doing the same thing that rate hikes do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in a way, that substitutes for rate hikes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, the key is, we have to have—policy has got to be tight enough to bring inflation down to 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It doesn’t all have to come from rate hikes: It can come from, you know, from tighter credit conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re looking at, and we, we—it’s highly uncertain how long the situation will be sustained or how significant any of those effects would be, so we’re just going to have to watch.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the meantime, you know—obviously, at the end of the day, we will do enough to bring inflation down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No one should doubt that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we’re well aware of the concentrations people have in commercial real estate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I really don’t think it’s comparable to this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The, the banking system is, is strong, it is sound, it is resilient, it’s well capitalized, and I really don’t see that as at all analogous to this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I welcome—it’s 100 percent certainty that there will be independent investigations and outside investigations and all that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we welcome—when a bank fails, there are investigations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, we welcome that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t assume that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t give advice to the fiscal authorities, and we assume that—we take fiscal policy as, as it comes to our front door, stick it in our model along with a million other things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have responsibility for price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Federal Reserve has responsibility for that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And nothing’s going to change that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and we will get inflation down to 2 percent in time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You have to look at, at the impulse from spending because spending was, of course, tremendously high during the pandemic, and then, as the pandemic programs rolled off, spending actually came down, so the—this sort of fiscal impulse is actually not what’s driving inflation right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was—it was at the beginning perhaps part of what was driving inflation, but that’s not really the story now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So 13(3) seemed like the right—we have a little more flexibility under section 13(3).

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve done quite a lot under the discount window as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We needed to do a special facility that was designed a certain way, so we did it under 13(3).

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Really no magic to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s only available in unusual and exigent circumstances, and it has to be—meet certain requirements, but it seemed to be the right place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So with the FDIC, we’re just, we’re lending to the, in effect, we’re—we’re lending to the bridge bank.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s where the March 22, 2023 funds came from, and it’s—it’s a loan that’s 100 percent guaranteed by the FDIC, so there’s no Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL risk in it for us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No, absolutely not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No, we, if we need to raise hike—raise rates higher, we will.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think for now though we, we—as I’ve mentioned, we see the likelihood of, of credit tightening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know that can have, you know, an effect on the macroeconomy, on demand, on labor market, on inflation, and we’re—we’re going to be watching to see what that is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll also be watching what’s happening with inflation and in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ll be watching all those things, and of course we will—we will eventually get to [a] tight enough policy to bring inflation down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll find ourselves at that place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—People think of QE and QT in different ways, so let me be clear about how I’m thinking about these recent developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the recent liquidity provision that has increased the size of our balance sheet but the intent and the effects of it are very different from what we—from when we expand our balance sheet through purchases of longer-term securities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Large-scale purchases of long-term securities are, are really meant to alter the stance of policy by pushing down—pushing up the price and down the rates, longer-term rates, which supports demand through channels we understand fairly well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The balance sheet expansion is really temporary lending to banks to meet those special liquidity demands created by the recent tensions; it’s not intended to directly alter the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do believe that it’s working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s having its intended effect of bolstering confidence in the banking system and thereby forestalling what might otherwise have been an abrupt and outsized tightening in financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the distribution of reserves, we, we don’t see ourselves as, as running into reserve shortages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we think that our program of allowing our balance sheet to, to run off predictably, predicatbly and passively is working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And of course we’re, we’re always prepared to, to change that if that changes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we don’t see any evidence that that’s changed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, to be honest, I don’t—I don’t recall the specifics of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s been quite an interesting seven weeks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, but I will tell you, though, that we have—there have been presentations about, about interest rate risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, it’s been in all the newspapers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not a surprise that there are institutions that have—that have had unhedged long positions in long-duration securities that have lost value as, as longer-term rates have gone up due to our rate increases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s not a surprise.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I think, as you know, as is now in the public record, the supervisory team was apparently engaged, very much engaged with the bank repeatedly, and was escalating but, you know, nonetheless, what happened happened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so that’s really the purpose of—one way to think about the review that Vice Chair Barr is conducting is to try to understand how that happened and try to understand how we can do better and what policies we need to change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, one thing is the speed of the—I’ll come back to that, the speed of the run, it’s very different from what we’ve seen in the past, and it does kind of suggest that there’s a need for possible, you know, regulatory and supervisory changes just because supervision and regulation need to keep up with what’s, what’s happening in the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will have to come back to you on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah, I don’t know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I’m not saying anything more than I’m saying.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—but what I’m saying is you’ve seen that we have the tools to protect depositors when there’s a threat of serious harm to the economy or to—or to the financial system, and we’re prepared to use those tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think depositors should assume that their—that their deposits are safe.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we—that was really the Swiss government that we of course were, were following it over the course of the weekend, and we were engaged with their authorities in the way that you would expect, all the ways that you would expect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It seems to have been a positive outcome in the sense that the transaction was agreed to, and it has been—the markets have accepted it, and it seems to have gone well, and I think there was a concern that it might not go well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So coming into the middle of this week, yes, I would say that that is going well so far.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s just—that’s an estimate of what will happen as demand slows and as conditions soften in the labor market and it’s just—it’s a highly uncertain estimate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, I mean, I was really—we have to bring inflation down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The costs of bringing it down—there are real costs to bringing it down to 2 percent, but the costs of failing are much higher.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if you read your history, as I’m sure you have, you can see that if the central bank doesn’t get inflation back in place, get inflation—make sure that inflation expectations remain anchored, you can have a long series of years where inflation is high and volatile, and it’s hard to invest capital, it’s hard for an economy to perform well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re looking to avoid that and, you know, to get back to where we need to be—back to where we were for a quarter century, and get there as quickly as we can.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, it depends on whether you—so recessions tend to be nonlinear, and so they’re very hard to model.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the models all work in a kind of linear way—if you have more of this, you get more of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But when a recession happens, the reactions tend to be nonlinear and that’s what—so we don’t know whether that’ll happen this time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t know—if so, we don’t know how significant it will be, and so, you know, we’re very focused on getting inflation down because we know in the longer run that that is the thing that will most benefit the people we serve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s how we can have a long—you know, we’ve had very strong March 22, 2023 labor markets through these long expansions that we’ve had.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Four of the five longest, or three of Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the four longest expansions in U.S. history have been really since the high-inflation period.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the reason was inflation wasn’t forcing the central bank to come in and stop an incipient or, or, you know, an expansion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can have very, very long expansions without high inflation, and we had several of those, and they’re very good for people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see late in an expansion—you see low unemployment, you see the benefits of wages going to people at the lower end of the wage spectrum.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just a place that we should try to get back to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know it’s, it’s too early to say, really, whether these events have had much of an effect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s hard for me to see how they would have helped the possibility—but I guess I would just say, it’s too early to say whether there really have been changes in that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the question will be how long this period is sustained.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The longer it’s sustained, then the greater will be the likely declines in—or tightening in credit standards, credit availability, so we’ll just have to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do still think, though, that there’s a—there’s a pathway to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that pathway still exists and, you know, we’re certainly trying to find it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But those are serious—those are serious regulatory, in particular immediate attention, and that’s—and I guess there were six of them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is a great question and is right in the heart of what the review will be doing under Vice Chair Barr’s leadership.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, I think that’s where—that’s what you think about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What can we do to make sure that—but, again, that’s not for me to answer today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well I, I—see, if I did, I wouldn’t share them because I, I really, you know, this review is going on, and, you know, I want nothing other than us to find out what happened and why, figure out what we can do to do better, and then implement those changes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s all I want.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—For me to be giving you my half-formed, or partially informed, thoughts, it, you know, just isn’t appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a real serious review going on with, with people from all over the Federal Reserve System who are not connected to this, you know, to this work, not connected to this bank, and under, again, Vice Chair Barr’s leadership, and I’m confident that it will produce a satisfactory result.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we haven’t really talked about changing the balance sheet implementation—that’s not something we’ve discussed yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, we’re always willing to change that if we conclude that it’s appropriate, but we’re really not seeing any signs there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sorry, then the question before that was, just give me a— JENNIFER SCHONBERGER.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Curious how you view financial conditions now and, if credit were to tighten enough, if that would prompt a rate cut.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So financial conditions seem to have tightened—and probably by more than the traditional indexes say, because traditional indexes are focused a lot on [interest] rates and [prices of] equities, and they don’t necessarily capture lending conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we think that, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there are other measures which, if they’re focused on, you know—bank lending conditions and things like that—they show some more tightening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then—and then, you know, once you have—once you know that, there’s a fair amount of research about how that, with broad uncertainty bands—how that works its way into the economy [and] over what period of time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so, you know, we’ll be looking to see the first part of that—like how serious is this, and does it look like it’s going to be sustained, and if it is, you know, it could easily have a significant macroeconomic effect, and we would factor that into our policy decisions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mentioned with rate cuts, rate cuts are not in our base case, and, you know, so that’s all I have to say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you very much.
